docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, cab drivers didn’t have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now they are “independent contractors,” a winsome way of saying they are carrying most of the risk.

headline.seo: As Pay of Cabbies Drops, a Bid for Their First Raise in Years
headline.main: Their Meters Keep Running, but the Fares Barely Make Ends Meet
headline.print_headline: Their Meters Keep Running, but the Fares Barely Make Ends Meet

docs.abstract: Michael Powell Gotham column commends Mayor Michael R Bloomberg for fighting to raise wages for New York City taxi drivers, but says he faces a hard fight against the politically-connected taxicab industry; notes that years ago drivers did not have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now, as independent contractors, the burden of a slow night of work falls heavily on the drivers, making it difficult to earn a living.
docs.snippet: Years ago, cab drivers didn’t have to rent their cabs or pay for gas, but now they are “independent contractors,” a winsome way of saying they are carrying most of the risk.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers critique a Republican proposal that David Brooks lauds.

headline.main: Differing Visions of Health Care Reform
headline.print_headline: Differing Visions of Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: Letter from Sen Tom Harkin of Iowa responds to July 3 David Brooks Op-Ed column on opposition to the Supreme Court's decision upholding the Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: Readers critique a Republican proposal that David Brooks lauds.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The law promises to give Americans with mental illness something they have never had before: near-universal health insurance, not just for their medical problems but for psychiatric disorders as well.

headline.seo: Health Care Law Offers Wider Benefits for Treating Mental Illness
headline.main: Good News for Mental Illness in Health Law
headline.print_headline: Good News for Mental Illness in Health Law

docs.abstract: Under health care reform law, psychiatric benefits will finally achieve parity with other medical coverage; until law's passage, people with mental illnesses and substance disorders have faced stingy annual and lifetime caps on coverage, higher deductibles or simply no coverage at all.
docs.snippet: The law promises to give Americans with mental illness something they have never had before: near-universal health insurance, not just for their medical problems but for psychiatric disorders as well.

headline.main: Obama Pushes Tax Cut Extension That Excludes Wealthiest

docs.lead_paragraph: A law that denies benefits to married same-sex spouses raises federalism concerns, say the law’s challengers.

headline.seo: An Unexpected Alliance in a Same-Sex Marriage Case
headline.main: Suit Cites States’ Rights on Behalf of Gay Rights
headline.print_headline: In the Next Term, A Possible Rematch On a Different Law

docs.abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column observes that Paul D Clement, the lawyer who led the attempt to overturn the Affordable Care Act, is now petitioning the Supreme Court to decide whether the Defense of Marriage Act is constitutional; notes the law's challengers argue that denying federal benefits to same-sex spouses under the marriage law raises federalist concerns that it oversteps Congress's power to attach conditions to federal grants to states.
docs.snippet: A law that denies benefits to married same-sex spouses raises federalism concerns, say the law’s challengers.
